chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any Electoral College reform should make the presidency follow voter intent more closely while preserving the federal benefit of state-run elections and geographically broad legitimacy. A workable middle path is to keep the Electoral College but replace winner-take-all with a uniform, proportional allocation rule in every state, alongside national baseline standards for voter access, paper-backed tabulation, risk-limiting audits, and automatic recount thresholds. If proportional allocation still fails to track the popular will over time, states could adopt a clearly defined National Popular Vote compact as a trigger-based backstop, giving the system a stable off-ramp without sudden disruption.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Presidential elections should more reliably reflect voters’ overall intent while keeping states central to running elections in a way people can verify and accept. A practical compromise is to end winner-take-all by allocating electoral votes proportionally in every state (with a National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as an optional backstop where adopted), so campaigns have incentives to compete beyond a few battlegrounds. Whichever allocation method is used, it should be paired with clear national baseline standards for ballot access, paper-backed tabulation, risk-limiting audits, and automatic recount triggers in close races to strengthen legitimacy across regions.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Presidential elections should be easy for ordinary voters to understand and trust: every lawful vote should matter in every state, results should be auditable, and the winner should reflect broad public support—not just a few battlegrounds. A practical compromise is to keep state-run elections but replace winner-take-all with proportional allocation of electors nationwide (or, if states agree, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a backstop), so fewer communities feel ignored. Whichever path is chosen, set clear national baseline rules for ballot access, paper records, risk-limiting audits, and automatic recount triggers, and consider ranked-choice voting or a runoff to reduce spoiler fears and reward candidates who can win wider support.
